etymologies: late Middle English (as a verb): from Old French vestu ‘clothed’, past participle of vestir, from Latin vestire; the noun (early 17th century, denoting a loose outer garment) from French veste, via Italian from Latin vestis ‘garment’

definitions: a sleeveless, close-fitting waist-length garment worn over a shirt, typically having no collar and buttoning down the front

examples.text: businessmen wear three-piece pin-striped suits with vests and neckties

definitions: a garment worn on the upper part of the body for a particular purpose or activity
shortDefinitions: similar garment worn on upper part of body for particular purpose or activity

definitions: an undershirt, typically one without sleeves.

examples.text: she stepped out in a striped vest and skinny jeans with strappy black heels
Kim looked chic in her pink jeans and white vest top

definitions: confer or bestow (power, authority, property, etc.) on someone

examples.text: executive power is vested in the President

shortDefinitions: confer or bestow (power, authority, property, etc.) on someone

definitions: give (someone) the legal right to power, property, etc.

examples.text: he alone is vested with the authority to steer the country’s economy

shortDefinitions: give someone legal right to power, property

definitions: (of power, property, etc.) come into the possession of

examples.text: the bankrupt's property vests in his trustee

definitions: (of a chorister or member of the clergy) put on vestments

examples.text: he approaches the altar to vest for Mass

shortDefinitions: (of chorister or member of clergy) put on vestments

examples.text: the Speaker vested him with a rich purple robe
